snippet.title: Private schools making a mark on the Coast
snippet.content: WHILE the Sunshine Coast has long enjoyed a reputation for providing excellent education, it is only in more recent years that large private schools have made their mark. Two examples are Matthew Flinders Anglican College and Sunshine Coast Grammar, which were not even thought of when the Sunshine Coast adopted its new name 50 years ago. Matthew Flinders had its genesis in 1988, when a sub-committee was formed under the Rural Deanery on the Sunshine Coast, with the view of starting an Anglican school. In April 1988, Rod Forrester was elected chairman by the parish representatives and led a feasibility study before an application was lodged with the federal government for approval to develop a school catering for students from pre-school to Year 12. On approval, the search began to find a name for the new school - something that would reflect the principles and standards the students would strive to uphold. In September 1988, the school was officially named Matthew Flinders Anglican College. A site was located, the land was purchased and construction began in September 1989. Enrolments opened and within one month, the college had more than 200 children registered. It opened in January 1990 with an enrolment of 161 students in Years 5-8. Six years later, Sunshine Coast Grammar School came to public attention, with the laying of its first foundation stone. In 1997, it opened its doors to around 300 students in Years 1-7 and the following year added pre-school and Year 8. Grammar's first Year 12 Students graduated in 2002. The school has continued to grow at a rapid rate, with a Leaf Early Learning Centre opening its doors in 2006 to cater for children from six weeks to school age. Its latest milestone project, the Grammar Aquatic Centre, will soon become a reality. The largest capital project in the history of the school, it will provide a world class, 10-lane, 50m FINA-certified heated swimming pool as well as an enclosed 15m learn-to-swim pool, a 700-seat undercover grandstand, a gymnasium, tennis centre, classrooms, change rooms and a kiosk. Matthew Flinders has also continued to grow and now has a student population of 1320 from Prep to Year 12. It has built an enviable reputation upon its students' academic performance, their commitment to personal achievement, coupled with their involvement in sports and the arts. An Early Learning Centre caters for 124 of the youngest in the community of learners as the school focuses on preparing students for a life "beyond the school gates". Grammar, too, is planning for the future and has embraced a vision for powerful learning, by helping its students become ethical, responsible and caring citizens of the world, with a digital mindset for the future. In 2013, it launched its digital 1:1 technology program, which means students have iPads, laptops, iwatches and iPods at their fingertips. Many free online coding resources offer students the opportunity to explore and create imaginary worlds online to share and play with other children from their classes or even across the globe.
